repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

physdesc.extent: 65 boxes, 9 oversized folders, 32 VHS cassette tapes

did.abstract: This collection contains memorabilia and other material relating to various graduating classes from Tufts University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized in two series: Classes, and Unprocessed accessions.

Material is added to the collection as it relates to graduating classes, so it is organized by class year, not date of the creation of the material. For example, a 50th reunion book for the class of 1928 would be in the series for the class of 1928, and not with material created in 1978.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Russell Elliott Miller was a Professor of History, University Historian and Archivist of Tufts University, and author of "Light on the Hill, A History of Tufts College from 1852 to 1952" and the second volume "Light on the Hill, A History of Tufts University since 1952." He was born in Bloomington, Minnesota, on April 25, 1916, to one of the last pioneer families in the Minnesota prairie. His mother spoke Dakota Sioux, which she had learned as a child. He received a B.A. in Education in 1937 and an M.A. in political science in 1939, both from the University of Florida at Gainesville. From 1942 to 1946, he served in the Army Air Corps as an enlisted man, rising to the rank of technical sergeant. Initially with personnel and classification, he was finally assigned to the historical section (intelligence) at the headquarters of the troop carrier command. In 1948 he earned a Master of Arts in history from Princeton University and came to Tufts that same year.

In 1952 he received a PhD from Princeton, and in 1964 Tufts appointed him Professor of History and University Historian and archivist. He taught courses ranging from the history of western civilization to the history of the American frontier. In 1966, he published "Light on the Hill, A History of Tufts College from 1852 to 1952." That year he received the Distinguished Service Award from the Tufts Alumni Association and became an honorary member of Phi Beta Kappa. In 1975 he became the Walter S. Dickson Professor of English and American History and chaired the Department of History from then until 1980. He was voted Emeritus Professor of English and American History in 1981 and received an honorary Doctor of Letters degree in 1983. In 1986, he completed the second volume of Tufts history, "Light on the Hill II, A History of Tufts University since 1952."

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The Classes collection was created by Russell Miller to organize material relating to individual classes that did not fit into any of his other subject categories. Material about individual classes is currently added to the collection.

All material accessioned prior to 1997 was originally arranged by subject, no attempt was made to recreate original order, although material relating to administering the collection was removed to the documentation files of the collection in the archives.

Most of the news clippings, photographs, press releases, and correspondence have been separated from the subject files. These types of materials are present however, throughout the subject files as well.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Jackson College for Women Records, 1871-1985. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains reunion notes and programs, class day and class activity books, scrapbooks, graduation ceremony records, and photographs of graduated classes from 1858 on. The collection also includes newspaper clippings, correspondence, audio and video recordings, and memorabilia such as graduation gowns, class rings, pins, and patches related to graduated classes.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The "Classes" collection was created by Russell Miller to organize material relating to individual classes that did not fit into any of his other subject categories. Material about individual classes is currently added to the collection. This collection contains reunion notes and programs, class day and class activity books, scrapbooks, and newspaper clippings of classes from 1858. Material is added to the collection as it relates to graduating classes, so it is organized by class year, not date of the creation of the material. For example, a 50th reunion book of the class of 1928, would be in the series of that class, and not with material created in 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically into groups by graduating class year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Program, suggestions to the class of sixty; John Wilkes Hammond's term bill, January 11, 1860, donated by great grandson Henry Hammond in April 2006. John Wilkes Hammond attended Tufts from 1856-1860. He marreid Clara Tweed, daughter of Tufts Professor Benjamin Franklin Tweed. Mr. Hammond later on served on the Massachusetts Superior Court and on the Supreme Judicial Court (1898-1913).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The embroidered medical seal was given to Dr. Naaman Steinberg upon his graduation from Tufts Medical School in 1919. Seal was sewed by a family member. Embroidery folded up amidst tissue paper (no folder). Seal was donated by Dr. Naaman Steinberg's, M 1919, daughter, Elizabeth Schwartzman in 2007; seal arrived at DCA via Cora C. Ho, MLS Deputy Director, HHSL (accession number 2007.022). Because the embroidery was smelling of mold when it arrived at DCA, it was removed from its frame, dried, and then stored in the box. The embroidery is stored in UIP/box 088.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This CD contains four mp3 files of Gwen Schneidkraut singing folk and rock songs while playing acoustic guitar. Gwen S1.mp3 and part of Gwen S2.mp3 were recorded on September 14, 1974 at MacPhie Dining Hall. The remainder of Gwen S2.mp3, as well as Gwen S3.mp3 and Gwen S4.mp3, were recorded on November 9, 1974. Though Gwen Schneidkraut is the primary performer, Leslie Cooper and Helen Cohen accompany her at different points during the recordings. All were occupational therapy students from the class of 1976. The sound quality of Gwen S1.mp3 is better than the other recordings. The CD also contains an MS Word .docx file detailing the contents of the CD, as well as an mp3 recording of a WGBH radio show from May 31, 1963, which has no connection to Tufts.
Song Listing:

Gwen S1.mp3 You Can Close Your Eyes Hard-Lovin' Loser Song written by Gwen Schneidkraut and her brother Ruby Tuesday These Days You Got to Hide Your Love Away Love Has No Pride I'm a Woman Summertime The Marvelous Toy

Gwen S2.mp3 Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow Something in the Way He Moves Help Me Make It Through the Night Marcie Carolina in My Mind Looking for You and I Don't Know Where Let It Be Love Has No Pride Love Me Like a Man Urge for Going

Gwen S3.mp3 No Regrets Reason to Believe Something's Wrong Yiddish song [title unintelligible] Kretchma Leaves That Are Green Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow Ring-Around-A-Rosy Rag There But For Fortune Pack Up Your Sorrows

Gwen S4.mp3 I Shall Be Released I Like Mountain Music The Song Is Love You Ain't Goin' Nowhere If I Had Wings These Days Single Girl Daddy, You Been On My Mind 4+20 Your Love's Return Until It's Time for You to Go
